folder: 12th Street (West) & Hudson Street, Manhattan, NY
text:
(1)
299-309 West 12th Street, and 317 West 12th Street at N.W. corner of Hudson Street.
March 29, 1928.
P. L. Sperr.

(2)
The same scene shortly after demolition of 299-309 West 12th Street.

NEG #3508  September 21, 1929.
P. L. Sperr.

folder: 8th Avenue & Hudson Street, Manhattan, NY
text:
Eighth Avenue, west side, north from its inception at Hudson Street, showing the triangular Abingdon Square that separates these thoroughfares. Across same is a row of buildings on the north side of W. 12th Street. These will be removed for the new apartment house site identified as No. 299 W. 12th Street. Buildings on the right and beyond the street car, extend from this street to Jane Street.
These are to remain.
May 30, 1929
P. L. Sperr

folder: Hudson Street & Bank Street, Manhattan, NY
text:
(1)
Abingdon Square, looking north from Hudson Street at Bank Street, where Eighth Avenue branches off to the right, showing a row of old houses on the 12th Street side of the square, shortly to be demolished. Jeffersonian Club (Democratic, 3rd A.D. South) is in the center of this block.

April 3, 1929.

P. L. Sperr, Photographer.

(2)
The same, showing houses on 12th Street side demolished, all but the corner one at 8th Street, which was spared.

To the right is a bandstand and comfort station, and behind it part of Abingdon Hotel and old houses.

May 27, 1930.

P. L. Sperr, Photographer.

(3)
The same, showing new apartment building No. 299 West 12th Street under construction. On right, last glimpse of Abingdon Hotel, about to be torn down.

February 6, 1931.

P. L. Sperr, Photographer.

folder: Bank Street & Hudson Street, Manhattan, NY
text:
Bank Street, north side, west from and including Hudson Street, at the southern end of Abingdon Square. Part of the Abingdon Square bandstand and comfort station is shown at the extreme right. The General Electric Supply Corporation Building is 585-591 Hudson Street, filling the block from Bank to Bethune Streets.

May 30, 1929.

P. L. Sperr.

folder: Hudson Street & 12th Street, Manhattan, NY
text:
612 to 622 Hudson Street, east side, from 12th (formerly Troy) to Jane Streets, shortly before demolition of 309-299 West 12th
Street and 612, 614 Hudson Street.
March 7, 1929.
P. L. Sperr.

folder: Hudson Street & 12th Street, Manhattan, NY
text:
Hudson Street, west side, from 12th (formerly Troy) Street to
Jane Street.
May 30, 1929.
P. L. Sperr.

folder: Hudson Street & Bethune Street, Manhattan, NY
text:
Hudson Street, west side, north from Abingdon Square just below Bethune Street, and showing two houses on the N.E. corner of 12th Street, across the park, which are shortly to be demolished. The Laura Spellman Y.W.C.A., on the S.W. corner of 12th Street, is
flying its flag at half-mast.
Other pictures of these buildings are also filed under Abingdon
Square.
May 30, 1929.
P. L. Sperr, Photographer.

folder: 8th Avenue & Hudson Street, Manhattan, NY
text:
Eighth Avenue, north from Hudson Street, showing in the foreground the Abingdon Square area. The Park identifying same is at the left. In the background, at 14th Street, appears the County Trust Company Building.

View 2 is the same area several years later and showing the new apartment houses that have sprung up around the Square. At the left is the 20 story building, No. 299 W. 12th Street. On the right is the 16-story structure, No. 20 Abingdon Square. On the margin one observes the 6-story residential building that replaced the former
Abingdon Hotel (demolished 1931) and adjacent homes.

The last is the latest of all three, having recently been completed. The other two were finished in 1931.

May 27. 1930 Neg. #2281
May 12, 1940

P.L. Sperr

folder: 8th Avenue & Hudson Street, Manhattan, NY
text:
Eighth Avenue, north from Hudson Street (left and foreground) showing the Abingdon Square locale and its towering apartment houses. They are the NO. 299 N. 12th Street and the NO. 20 Abingdon Square buildings. Between same appears the County Trust Company Building at 14th Street. In the right foreground is the park that identifies this area. This is triangular in shape and is formed by the convergence of Hudson Street and the beginning of 8th Avenue. The bandstand at the right is on Bank Street. Bleecker Street separates this from the clearance shown. In 1939 a modern 6-story apartment house
will rise here, bearing an Abingdon Square address.

Views 2 and 3 emphasize the clearance and adjoining structures. Note the absence of the 12th Street building.

Views 1,2: June 18, 1931
View 3: Marcl 9, 1933
P. L. Sperr

folder: Bank Street & Hudson Street, Manhattan, NY
text:
(1)
Abingdon Square, looking north from Hudson Street at Bank Street, where Eighth Avenue branches off to the right.

New apartment buildings, 299 West 12th Street on north side of square, and building at S.E. corner of Eighth Avenue and 12th Street. Behind bandstand is vacant lot where Abingdon Hotel has been demolished.

March 15, 1932.
P. L. Sperr, Photographer.

(2)
The same view as No. 1 but four months later, showing in background the skeleton of Port Authority Building between Eighth and Ninth Avenues just north of 14th Street.

July 17, 1932.
P. L. Sperr, Photographer.
Neg #2282

(3)
The same view at a later date.

October 2, 1938.

P. L. Sperr.

text:
12th Street (formerly Troy Street), south side, east from Hudson
Street (Abingdon Square), late in the winter.
March 12, 1933.
P. L. Sperr.
(2)
The same, late the same spring.
May 20, 1933.

folder: Bank Street & Hudson Street, Manhattan, NY
text:
Abingdon Square, looking north on Eighth Avenue (left) and east on Bank Street (right) from S.W. corner of Bank and Hudson Streets, showing the bandstand and comfort station, used for Sunday afternoon concerts by Jeffersonian (Democratic) Club. Behind bandstand is a lot left vacant by demolition of Abingdon Hotel and adjoining old houses; two squatters will be camping there during 1934.

Loew's Sheridan Theatre cuts off Bank Street at the farther end.

March 12, 1933.

P.L. Sperr, Photographer.

folder: Hudson Street & Bethune Street, Manhattan, NY
text:
General Electric Supply Corporation, 591, 587-585 Hudson Street,
west side, from Bethune to Bank Streets.
At this point the distance between Hudson and Greenwich Streets
is at its minimum. See also Abingdon Square.
March 12, 1933.
P. L. Sperr.

folder: Hudson Street & Bethune Street, Manhattan, NY
text:
Hudson Street, west side, from Bethune to Jane Streets, seen
across Abingdon Square (q.v.).
March 12, 1933.
P. L. Sperr.

folder: Hudson Street & Bethune Street, Manhattan, NY
text:
597 to 607-609 Hudson Street, west side, Abingdon Square, from Bethune to 12th (formerly Troy) Streets. No. 599 Hudson Street (16 Abingdon Square) is the home (since 1929) of the Jeffersonians, the Tammany club for the Third Assembly District South. See Abingdon Square. The clearing in the foreground is the site of the Abingdon Hotel at 7 Abingdon Square.
No. 607-609 is the Laura Spellman Y.W.C.A.
March 12, 1933.
P. L. Sperr.

folder: Hudson Street & 12th Street, Manhattan, NY
text:
Hudson Street, east side, from 12th (formerly Troy Street) to 14th Streets and Ninth Avenue, the northern end of Hudson Street. At the right is shown the Hudson Street side of the new 299 West 12th Street apartment building.
March 12, 1933.
P. L. Sperr.

folder: Hudson Street & Bank Street, Manhattan, NY
text:
Hudson Street, west side, from Bank (left of No. 1), to W. 12th (right of No. 2) Streets, showing buildings thereupon as viewed across a clearance on the east side of Abingdon Square
between Bank Street and Eighth Avenue.

The thoroughfare in the center separating these blocks is Bethune Street and thru which appears a glimpse of the Ninth Avenue "El" running on Greenwich Street. The G. E. Supply Corp. building occupies the Bank-Bethune Street frontage, while to the north are dwellings between Bethune and W. 12th Streets.

Eighth Avenue begins at this point and runs at the right over the exposed sub-basement and to the front of the exposed building rears.

The six story building with the white trim, located at the S. W. corner of Hudson and W. 12th Streets is the Laura Spellman Hall of the Young Women's Christian Association. The trees partially hiding same are in the triangular park named for the daughter of Sir Peter Warren. This separates Eighth Avenue from Hudson Street.

Upon the foreground site formerly stood No's. 1, 3, 5, and 7-9 Abingdon Square (q.v.); the last being the Abingdon Hotel. These were demolished in May 193l.

1933
Views: 1-3

Gift of Committee on Housing
Charity Organization Society

folder: 8th Avenue & Hudson Street, Manhattan, NY
text:
Eighth Avenue, (left) east side, north from Hudson Street (foreground), showing the bandstand silhouetted against a new 6-story apartment house. The latter is on Bleecker Street, between the Avenue and Bank Street (right). Irrespective of this, it will bear an Abingdon Square number. To the left is the 16-story apartment house, No. 20 Abingdon Square, located at the S. E. corner of 8th Avenue and W. 12th Street.

View 2 is limited to first mentioned feature. The dark 5-story dwelling at the left is No. 4 Abingdon Square.

May 12, 1940
April 9, 1940

P. L. Sperr
